title: Can I add a debt that arose after I filed my Chapter 7 bankruptcy?
question: I filed a BK and was the plaintiff in a state court lawsuit. The trustee abandoned my case. I lost the case after filing my BK and the other side got a judgment against me for $37,000 in attorney fees.
answers: The real question is whether or not your civil litigation case was file prior to you filing your BK Petition. If so, you should have listed it as a possible asset. Moreover, if this (done prior to your filing BK) the automatic stay should have been in place prohibiting the civil case from proceeding, especially the defendant obtaining a judgment against you. I think you have a decent argument that the debt or the reasonable foreseeability of it arose prior to the filing of the BK. Basically, all debts incurred prior to the filing of the BK are subject to being discharged. Thus, since your case is still open you should amend your schedules and add him as a creditor. If your case is what is called a "no asset" case then this should be a simple procedure.

Any liability which arose prior to the date you filed your bankruptcy can be part of the bankruptcy. In fact, it should have already been disclosed to the Trustee. In the Tenth Circuit, if you are a no asset case (the trustee does not take any of your property and pay a dividend to your creditors) , even undisclosed creditors are discharged. The Ninth Circuit, where you are, may be different. In any case, you need to amend the schedules to disclose the omitted creditor. See a bankruptcy attorney right away. Do not wait. This is one of those cases where trying to save money by doing your own bankruptcy may end up costing you much more than if you have hired an attorney in the first place.

I believe Shaye Larking Attorney is right. I receive all Bankruptcy Reporters which disclose all published cases . I have read cases where in fact as a result of you pursuing the lawsuit post petition, you ran the risk of losing..which is one reason I discuss with my clients waiting till it is over with before filing, or running the risk of losing..Now if you do lose, as you did, there is case authority on the attorney fees incurred Post Petition, Not Pre petition are not discharged (assuming there is a valid basis under the law to imposed liability for attorney fees also). If not too late, I would do as one attorney indicated to amend the schedules and make sure listed in all places noted by the attorneys, but you might also file a motion for reconsideration of the civil case judge that any attorneys fees you are liable for should ONLY be post petition fees as the others would be discharged upon you receiving a discharge! Good luck...Because you indicate you already made payments on the judgment, your time with the court may have expired possibly but talk to an attorney on that. But if so, maybe a motion in Bankruptcy Court to find that the portion of attorney fees awarded in the civil court that were incurred pre petition should be found to be discharged. Maybe an agreed order with the other attorney awarded the fees could resolve it also if they agree or you can threaten additional fees for violation of the discharge. Finally, unless your debt falls w/in one of the exceptions to discharge, do not forget you can always do a chapter 13..but waiting till 4 yrs after the ch 7 petition date if possible may cause you to have to pay out less monies than the 100% requirement if you file less than 4 yrs after the ch 7 date. Good luck.

Being a plaintiff in a lawsuit should have been disclosed in your BK papers in at least two places:
(1) Schedule B as a potential asset;
(2) Statement of Financial Affairs where you are a party to a lawsuit.

Since the Causes of Action existed prior to filing BK, and the "asset" turned out to be a "liability" you can amend Schedule F to add it the judgment against you for atty fees. Don't wait too long or your case can be closed and adding the debt might require a motion to reopen the case and payment of additional fees. Good luck.

The amendment can be filed perhaps but full facts are not clear. If the "other attorney" stated to you that the amendment can be filed, what is stopping you. It is always good to hire licensed attorney. I am sure if your BK is not closed, an amendment can be filed. You definitely needs a qualified and a local help in this regard.

If I understand you correctly, you are the plaintiff but you lost the lawsuit and a judgment was entered against you after the day your bankruptcy was filed. Now there is a liability against you for attorneys fees. A debt incurred after the day the bankruptcy is filed will not be included in the discharge, but perhaps an argument can be made that at least some of the attorney fees were incurred and therefore owed prior to the date of the filing of your bankruptcy? If the lawsuit was going on before you filed your case, it would seem that at least some of those fees were incurred pre-bk. I am interested to see what other attorneys think about this.

This is a question that cannot be answered without reference to undisclosed facts. On your bare statement of facts, both attorneys are right. You are going to have to pay for advice on this one.

The issue may turn on whether the creditor obtained relief from stay and the terms of the abandonment order. For a recent case discussing one aspect of this issue, see In re Gasprom at http://cdn.ca9.uscourts.gov/datastore/bap/2013/10/28/Gasprom-12-1567.pdf.

I hope you will not make the same mistake twice and attempt to handle his matter on your own. You may find it better to dismiss and refile but you should only do so upon the advice and recommendation of an attorney hired to handle the dismissal and refiling for you. Good luck.

It is not the judgment date that counts it is the cause of action. Plaintiff says you owe money for something that happened at an earlier time, presumably before you filed your Chapter 7. You should be able to amend your schedules. Discuss this with a BK lawyer.
